title: 115_hr1574
content: The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" is a bill that aims to provide viewpoint protection in communications. It amends Title I of the Communications Act of 1934 to include provisions for protecting viewpoints. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the revocation of licenses or other actions based on viewpoints expressed in broadcast content. It also prohibits placing conditions on viewpoints in transaction reviews. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits revocation of licenses or actions based on broadcast content viewpoints. It also prohibits placing conditions on viewpoints in transaction reviews. The Act does not affect the Commission's authority to take action on violations of specific sections of the United States Code. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits actions based on broadcast content viewpoints, violations of specific sections of the United States Code, and incitement under the First Amendment. The President is also restricted from directing agencies to retaliate against individuals based on their viewpoints. The President is prohibited from directing agencies to take actions against individuals based on their viewpoints on public issues in broadcast content. This includes not placing conditions on approvals or decisions related to the viewpoints expressed by the person seeking approval. The President is prohibited from directing agencies to take actions against individuals based on their viewpoints on public issues in broadcast content. This includes not placing conditions on approvals or decisions related to the viewpoints expressed by the person seeking approval or decision. The President is prohibited from directing agencies to take actions against individuals based on their viewpoints on public issues in broadcast content, including incitement under the First Amendment to the Constitution. The term "agency" in this subsection refers to its definition in section 551 of title 5, United States Code.
